title: Claud Jacob
text:
<a href="Field%20marshal%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Field Marshal</a> Sir Claud William Jacob, (21 November 1863 – 2 June 1948) was a <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">British Indian Army</a> officer. He served in the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> as commander of the Dehra Dun Brigade, as General Officer Commanding <a href="21st%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">21st Division</a> and as General Officer Commanding <a href="II%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">II Corps</a> in the <a href="Fifth%20Army%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Fifth Army</a>. During the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Somme">Battle of the Somme</a>, his corps undertook the British attack during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Thiepval%20Ridge">Battle of Thiepval Ridge</a> in September 1916 and the subsequent assault on St Pierre Divion during the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Ancre">Battle of the Ancre</a> in November 1916. He remained in command of II Corps for the <a href="Battle%20of%20Passchendaele">Battle of Passchendaele</a> in Autumn 1917. After the War he commanded a corps of the <a href="British%20Army%20of%20the%20Rhine">British Army of the Rhine</a> during the <a href="occupation%20of%20the%20Rhineland">occupation there</a> and then served as <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20General%20Staff%20%28India%29">Chief of the General Staff in India</a>. He went on to be General Officer Commanding <a href="Northern%20Command%20%28India%29">Northern Command</a> in India before temporarily becoming <a href="Commander-in-Chief%2C%20India">Commander-in-Chief, India</a> and then taking over as <a href="Military%20Secretary%20to%20the%20India%20Office">Military Secretary to the India Office</a>.
Military career.
Jacob was born on 21 November 1863, at <a href="Mahidpur">Mahidpur</a> in the <a href="Bombay%20Presidency">Bombay Presidency</a> of <a href="British%20India">British India</a>, to Major-General William Jacob and Eliza Jacob.
Educated at <a href="Sherborne%20School">Sherborne School</a>, he passed into <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%20Sandhurst">Sandhurst</a> and was commissioned into the <a href="Worcestershire%20Regiment">Worcestershire Regiment</a> on 9 September 1882. On 16 December 1884, stationed at <a href="Quetta">Quetta</a>, he secured his transfer from the Worcestershire Regiment to the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">Indian service</a> and, in July 1886, he became adjutant of the <a href="130th%20Baluchis">30th Regiment (Jacob's) Bombay Native Infantry</a> also known as 3rd Belooch Regiment (now 12 Baloch). He first saw action with the Zhob Valley expedition of 1890 after which he was posted to the <a href="124th%20Duchess%20of%20Connaught%27s%20Own%20Baluchistan%20Infantry">24th (Baluchistan) Regiment of Bombay Infantry</a> (now 6 Baloch) in 1891. Promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> on 9 September 1893 and to <a href="major">major</a> on 10 July 1901, he was selected to command the Zhob Levy Corps, which kept the peace in the <a href="North-West%20Frontier%20Province%20%281901%E2%80%931955%29">North West Frontier Province</a> along the <a href="Waziristan">Waziristan</a> and Southern <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> border. He took part in the blockade of the <a href="Mahsud">Mahsud</a> <a href="Wazir%20%28Pashtun%20tribe%29">Waziri</a> tribe at the end of 1901. Promoted to <a href="lieutenant-colonel">lieutenant-colonel</a> on 1 October 1904, he was given command of the <a href="106th%20Hazara%20Pioneers">106th Hazara Pioneers</a>. Promoted to brevet colonel on 1 October 1908 and to full <a href="colonel">colonel</a> on 1 January 1911, he was appointed <a href="Staff%20%28military%29">GSO1</a> of the Meerut Division on 2 September 1912.
At the outbreak of the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a> in 1914, Jacob went with the Meerut division, part of the Indian corps, to the <a href="Western%20Front%20%28World%20War%20I%29">Western Front</a>. He saw action at the closing stages of the <a href="Battle%20of%20La%20Bass%C3%A9e">Battle of La Bassée</a> in October 1914. Promoted to temporary <a href="brigadier-general">brigadier-general</a> on 5 January 1915, he was appointed to command the Dehra Dun Brigade, and led the brigade at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Neuve%20Chapelle">Battle of Neuve Chapelle</a> in March 1915 and the <a href="Battle%20of%20Aubers%20Ridge">Battle of Aubers Ridge</a> in May 1915. Promoted to temporary <a href="major-general">major-general</a> on 7 September 1915, he became General Officer Commanding the Meerut division and led the division at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Loos">Battle of Loos</a> in October 1915. With the Indian Corps was preparing to leave the Western front, he was appointed to take over the <a href="21st%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">21st Division</a> of the "New Armies" on 18 November 1915. Promoted to the substantive rank of major-general on 1 January 1916 and despite being wounded in March 1916, he was promoted to temporary <a href="lieutenant-general">lieutenant-general</a> on 28 May 1916 and appointed to command <a href="II%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">II Corps</a> in the <a href="Fifth%20Army%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Fifth Army</a> in September 1916. During the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Somme">Battle of the Somme</a>, his corps undertook the British attack during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Thiepval%20Ridge">Battle of Thiepval Ridge</a> in September 1916 and the subsequent assault on St Pierre Divion during the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Ancre">Battle of the Ancre</a> in November 1916. He remained in command of II Corps, having been promoted to the substantive rank of <a href="lieutenant-general">lieutenant-general</a> on 3 June 1917, for the <a href="Battle%20of%20Passchendaele">Battle of Passchendaele</a> in Autumn 1917.
Jacob commanded a corps of the <a href="British%20Army%20of%20the%20Rhine">British Army of the Rhine</a> during the <a href="occupation%20of%20the%20Rhineland">occupation there</a>. He became <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20General%20Staff%20%28India%29">Chief of the General Staff in India</a> in January 1920 and was then both promoted to full <a href="general">general</a> and appointed <a href="Aide-de-Camp">Aide-de-Camp</a> to <a href="George%20V%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">King George V</a> on 31 May 1920. He returned home to <a href="England">England</a> in 1924, and in November of that year was given the <a href="Northern%20Command%20%28India%29">Northern Command</a> in India. When <a href="Henry%20Rawlinson%2C%201st%20Baron%20Rawlinson">Lord Rawlinson</a> died in March 1925, he acted temporarily as <a href="Commander-in-Chief%2C%20India">Commander-in-Chief, India</a>, until <a href="William%20Birdwood">Sir William Birdwood</a> took over that role in August 1925 and Jacob returned home again. He took up the appointment of <a href="Military%20Secretary%20to%20the%20India%20Office">Military Secretary to the India Office</a> in April 1926 and, having been promoted <a href="Field%20marshal%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">field marshal</a> on 30 November 1926, he remained at the India Office until he retired in May 1930.
In retirement Jacob became <a href="Constable%20of%20the%20Tower">Constable</a> of the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a>. He was also Colonel of 2nd Battalion The Baluch Regiment (now 7th Battalion The <a href="Baloch%20Regiment">Baloch Regiment</a>), Colonel of the <a href="106th%20Hazara%20Pioneers">106th Hazara Pioneers</a> and Colonel of the <a href="Worcestershire%20Regiment">Worcestershire Regiment</a>. In January 1936 he attended the funeral of <a href="George%20V">King George V</a> and in May 1937 he attended the coronation of <a href="George%20VI">King George VI</a>. He died at <a href="King%27s%20College%20Hospital">King's College Hospital</a> in London on 2 June 1948 at the age of eighty-four.
Family.
In 1894, he married Clara Pauline Wyatt, daughter of the Reverend J. L. Wyatt, well known as a missionary and student of oriental languages in India, and also a lecturer in Tamil at <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a> from 1895 to 1929. The couple had one son, <a href="Ian%20Jacob">Edward Ian Claud Jacob</a>, who later became Assistant Military Secretary of the War Cabinet and <a href="Director-General%20of%20the%20BBC">Director-General of the BBC</a>.
